lesson.name: Part 2: Teaching Reading and Listening Strategies With Nonfiction Texts

page.title: Texts Adult English Language Learners Encounter
page.contents:
Adult ELLs spend a lot of time in English class reading short narratives or descriptive texts rather than informational or procedural texts found in work or postsecondary settings (Parrish & Johnson, 2010).

Think about the kinds of texts learners are likely to encounter at work, at school, and in their communities:

Workplace

  • Charts and graphs
  • Flowcharts
  • Work schedules
  • Handbooks
  • Instructional manuals
  • Safety guidelines

Academic

  • Articles
  • Textbooks
  • Charts, graphs, and graphic organizers
  • Class schedules

Community

  • Brochures
  • Announcements
  • Correspondence from schools

page.title: Informational or Procedural Texts
page.contents:
Informational TextsProcedural Texts
An informational text conveys factual information about the natural or social world. A procedural text gives instructions on how to do something.
  • Textbooks
  • Articles (magazines, journals, or newspapers)
  • Biographies
  • Brochures

These texts inform, whether for school, further training, work, or personal interest. They often contain supporting visuals but may have more academic language (see Unit 1).
  • Handbooks
  • Instructional manuals
  • Safety guidelines
  • Product directions

These texts often contain technical terms. They require the ability to follow multi-step directions. They may contain diagrams and supporting visuals.

page.title: Other Types of Nonfiction Texts
page.contents:
Environmental PrintCharts or Graphics
Texts that surround us in our everyday lives A Texts that require "graphic" literacy.
  • Menus
  • Signs
  • Advertisements

Understanding these types of texts helps adult ELLs fulfill their everyday needs, such as reading prices or recognizing street signs.
  • Schedules
  • Time sheets
  • Performance reviews
  • Report cards
  • Graphs, tables, and charts

These kinds of texts are very common in workplace settings.

page.title: Bonus Skills to Add Rigor to This Lesson
page.contents:
• Reading and filling in a graphic organizer is a scaffold for and a precursor to note taking.
  • Using a short, nonfiction text with beginners represents the kind of text they may encounter when assisting their children with homework or in a class working toward a high school equivalency diploma.
  • Learning about a political figure addresses a topic that may be of interest to adult learners.

Now let's turn to an intermediate-advanced reading lesson.

Remember...think about how you could use these activities and ideas in your classes or program.

page.title: Teaching Reading Strategies Using Informational Text
page.contents:
In this video from the New American Horizons Foundation (2012–2013), George Schooley, an ESL teacher at the Ronald M. Hubbs Center for Lifelong Learning in St. Paul, MN, uses a nonfiction text on birth-order theory with an intermediate- to advanced-level class. He demonstrates the following:

  • The connection between prior knowledge and reading
  • Multiple reading strategies
  • The connection between reading and critical thinking
  • The use of the Jigsaw reading technique
  • The use of graphic organizers in a reading lesson

TASK: Before viewing the video, open the Reading Lesson Observation Task. As you view the lesson, note the strategies addressed and practiced in the lesson on the observation task. Note where learners also are getting practice in note taking, critical thinking, and effective communication skills.

page.title: Strategies Practiced in George’s Lesson
page.contents:
ActivitiesStrategies Addressed
Grouping by birth order and identifying pros/cons; making predictions about the theory based on experience Anticipate content; preview and predict. Also, T-chart allowed them to organize their ideas logically.
Read once to check predictions. Read to confirm predictions; students also may scan to find any words that match their predictions.
Jigsaw Part 1: Read to fill in one branch of the tree diagram

Scan and then read for detail


Because of the nature of the task, learners could practice scanning to find five personality traits and three professions. They can look for key words that tell us the information they need. Given enough time, learners also can read the text more closely.
Jigsaw Part 2: Mingle to complete the tree diagram Recognize the structure of a text through the graphic organizer and then find further evidence to support a claim, the theory of personality and birth order.
Sorting vocabulary Make inferences: Learners must determine the connotations of the traits explored in the reading.
Follow-up interview Analyze relationships within a text and also challenge the validity of the theory (see more on these critical-thinking skills in Unit 4 of this module). Synthesize information we hear with information from other sources.

Listen to Audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0090.mp3

Audio transcript


What did you discover? Each task aligns with a particular reading strategy. For example, when teams make predictions about personality traits and their own birth order, the first reading task is to read to confirm predictions. This focuses learners’ attention on the connections between their own experiences or prior knowledge and what the text says. When they read to fill in one portion of the tree diagram, they use the strategy of reading for specific information. As they mingle to complete the full tree diagram, they can see the structure of the text overall and also find evidence to support the claim, or theory. As they sort the vocabulary, they need to recognize the connotations of the traits explored in the reading. Does the text paint a positive or a negative picture of each birth order? As homework, learners are asked to develop a question to interview others about their birth order to determine the validity of the theory. George’s lesson also incorporated extensive discussion and community building among his learners. A lesson similar to this one would be ideal for a student such as Carlos.

page.title: How Do We Listen?
page.contents:
In our everyday lives, we listen for different purposes and in different ways.

Write ideas about how you listen to each of the following. For example, when you have the news on, do you listen to every detail? How about at a work meeting? If you are working with colleagues on this unit, share your ideas. Otherwise, save your answers for later reference.

How do you listen to voicemail messages?

How do you listen to a news report on television, the radio, or online?

How do you listen to a lecture or a speech?

How do you listen in a work meeting? How about when your supervisor is giving you some instructions?

page.title: Purposes for Listening: Personal and Professional
page.contents:
To seek specific information:

  • Listen to a weather report for low and high temperatures.
  • Make decisions about how to dress appropriately or decide if it is safe to travel.

To gain a general idea of the topic:

  • Listen to news reports on television.
  • Pay attention to headlines of interest.
  • Ignore detailed information.

To gain knowledge:

  • Listen to a lecture, a presentation, or a training.
  • Listen to directions from a supervisor.
  • Listen more attentively for detail.
  • Complete a task or learn a new skill.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0100.mp3

Audio transcript


What did you discover? We listen to a variety of texts types: voicemail, TV and radio reports, lectures, interviews, instructions from supervisors, and more. We also listen for a variety of purposes. Sometimes we need to seek specific information. For people living in Minnesota, they might listen to a weather report for low and high temperatures and the chances of snow or severe wind chills so that they can dress appropriately or decide if it is safe to travel. Sometimes we just need to glean the general idea of the topic. In listening to news reports on TV, people may pay attention to those headlines in the news that interest them or have an impact on their lives. They may ignore detailed information. Sometimes we listen very carefully to gain knowledge. At work, in a presentation, or during training, people may listen more attentively for detail because they need to complete a task or learn a new skill.

page.title: Listening Strategies We Use Every Day
page.contents:
StrategyPurpose
Anticipate content; preview and predict Approach a listening situation with expectations
Listen to confirm predictions Check to see if our predictions are right or wrong.
Listen for gist Filter out many of the details and zero in on the key concepts of importance or interest to us.
Listen for specific information Listen only for information we need.
Listen for details Listen for detail, or understand the listening passage in its entirety (intensive listening).
Make inferences Interpret and make inferences about what we hear.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0110.mp3

Audio transcript


In our day-to-day lives, we employ a variety of listening strategies. We approach a listening situation with expectations. At the start of a talk, we expect the speaker to introduce us to the topic; during a meeting, we expect a supervisor to set expectations for the day or the week.

As we listen, we check to see if our predictions are right or wrong. In listening to the news headlines, we may filter out many of the details and just zero in on the key concepts of importance or interest to us. In listening to our voicemail messages, we may listen only for the names and phone numbers and write those down. Listening for detail involves intensive listening, or trying to understand the listening passage in its entirety. We may listen intensively to lectures or directions from a supervisor. If we receive a message with detailed information about a job interview, we probably listen for details and may even replay the message a few times. As we listen, we interpret and make inferences about what we hear. After hearing a politician’s views on a particular issue, we may be able to make inferences about the way he or she might vote on an upcoming bill.

page.title: Strategies for Comprehending Complex Oral Texts at Work, School, and Home
page.contents:
StrategyPurpose
Recognize purpose (of a report, interview, meeting) Listen for signal words that introduce  the topic and the purpose for listening.
Use visual or other clues Pay attention to nonverbal cues such as facial expressions and body language; make use of other visual supports available while listening, such as graphics or pictures during a presentation.
Find evidence to support claims Listen for examples and evidence and the signal words that go along with that information (For example….; Here are three reasons why…)
Transfer information to other contexts Use the information heard to engage in a follow-up discussion, make a decision, or complete a task.
Synthesize information we hear with information from other sources Draw on information from multiple sources, including what heard in a talk, a lecture, or a meeting.
Analyze relationships within a text Interpret and make inferences about what we hear.

Listen to Audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0120.mp3

Audio transcript


We employ many of the same strategies while listening that we use while reading; however, while reading we can take our time and reread a text many times. We do not have that luxury when listening outside the classroom. We listen for signal words that introduce us to the topic and the purpose for listening. We pay attention to nonverbal cues such as facial expressions and body language; we may have other visual supports available while listening, such as graphics or pictures during a presentation. We listen for examples and evidence and the signal words that go along with that information (For example….; Here are three reasons why…).

In work and school contexts, we often need to use the information we have heard to engage in a follow-up discussion, make a decision, or complete a task. In work and school contexts, we draw on information from multiple sources, including what we hear in a talk, a lecture, or a meeting. As we listen, we interpret and make inferences about what we hear. After hearing a politician’s views on a particular issue, we may be able to make inferences about the way he or she might vote on an upcoming bill. Now see how we can apply the strategies in a low-intermediate-level listening lesson.

page.title: Low-Intermediate-Level English Language Acquisition Class
page.contents:
Excerpt used with permission from the author, Lia Conklin Olson, Ronald Hubbs Center, ST. Paul ABE.

Prelistening Activities

Part 1: Vocabulary: Match the words with the definitions (Words and definitions are cut up and put in envelopes for small groups of students to match.)

Convenient A machine where you can withdraw cash
Credit card A paper holder for letters or money
ATM Allows you to buy things with borrowed money
Debt A group of things that are similar
Envelope Something that is easy to go or get
Entertainment When you owe more money than you have
Category (categories) Fun things to do

Build background knowledge; anticipate content:

  • Fill in gaps in prior knowledge about the topic.
  • Collaborate to figure out meanings by the process of elimination.
  • Preview theme by working on key vocabulary from the listening.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0130.mp3

Audio transcript


Many textbooks and curricula include listening passages with a series of questions (true/false; open ended, or multiple choice). See what happens when learners engage in a variety of tasks, including predicting, filling in a graphic organizer, and more.

Let’s start with the prelistening activities. In the column on the left, note the listening strategies a learner can employ to complete each task. For this first prelistening activity, collaborative word matching allows learners to fill in gaps in prior knowledge about a topic. Group matching provides opportunities for co-learning and figuring out meanings by the process of elimination. The vocabulary chosen serves to preview the theme of the listening text as well. We often preteach vocabulary with visuals, which is essential with beginners. In academic or work settings, however, there may be no visual supports. Matching words to simple definitions gives learners practice with English-English dictionaries.

page.title: Low-Intermediate-Level English Language Acquisition Class
page.contents:
Learners engage collaboratively in making predictions about what they will hear. Prelistening activities are essential for building background knowledge and can take as long as the actual listening activities.

Prelistening Activities
Part 2: Make predictions

We will hear Rene talk about a problem she has with credit cards in her life. Based on the words we practiced, what do you think she will tell us? With your partner, make three predictions:

1. __________________

2. __________________

3. __________________

Make predictions

  • Make logical guesses based on vocabulary presented and prior knowledge about credit cards
  • Focus on listening for predictions.

Listen to Audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0140.mp3

Audio transcript


For the second prelistening activity, learners engage collaboratively in making predictions about what they will hear. Prelistening activities are essential for building background knowledge and can take as long as the actual listening activities. Using knowledge about the topic from vocabulary and prior experiences with credit cards, adult ELLs practice making logical guesses about what they will hear. Anticipating content provides a focus for listening when they hear the passage again.

page.title: Low-Intermediate-Level English Language Acquisition Class page 1
page.contents:
Listen to confirm predictions

  • Confirm predictions to promote active listening.
  • Listen to check predictions personalize the task.

Listening Task 1
Listen to Rene talk about credit cards in her life. Check to see if your predictions were right or wrong.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0150.mp3

Audio transcript


For the first listening task, learners just check to see if their predictions are right or wrong. This task demonstrates to learners that making predictions promotes active listening. Listening to check their predictions personalizes the task.

Now listen to what the learners hear:

A Problem With Credit Cards

In the past, I never saw any problem using credit cards. They are more convenient and certainly quicker than trying to remember to get out cash from the ATM before I go shopping. I never thought using a credit card was a problem until I noticed that I charged more than I had in my bank account. I used my credit card to buy things when I did not have any money saved to pay for them. I got more and more into debt.

Then I learned about a new idea. My friend told me that if I take out cash after I put my check into my bank account, I could save money. He said that if I put my cash into different envelopes, such as “food,” “entertainment,” and “shopping,” then I could limit how much I spend on each category each month. Here’s how it works. I can spend only what I have in each envelope for that pay period. When the money in an envelope is gone, I cannot spend anymore in that category. I need to wait until my next paycheck and put more money in the envelopes. I started this process a couple months ago. Since I began, I have not had any more debt. I only spend the money I have. I am very responsible now with my spending.

page.title: Teaching Listening Strategies Using Short Video Clips
page.contents:
In this video, Jessica Jones of Open Door Learning Center in St. Paul MN uses short, teacher-made videos about people's experiences coming to a new culture. She demonstrates the following:

  • The connection between background knowledge and listening strategies instruction
  • Multiple listening strategies
  • The connection between listening and critical thinking
  • The use of the Jigsaw listening technique
  • The use of graphic organizers in a listening lesson

TASK: Before viewing the video, open and print Jessica's lesson plan and the Listening Lesson Observation Task. As you view the lesson, note the strategies addressed and practiced in the lesson. Note where learners also get practice in note taking, critical thinking, or effective communication skills.

page.title: Debriefing the Video Observation
page.contents:
If you are working with colleagues, share what you found.

  • How did Jessica's choice of activities promote practice with particular listening strategies?
  • How did she promote meaningful interactions among learners?
  • What were the benefits of using the grid graphic organizer? What were the benefits of the jigsaw approach?

Now let's see how your findings compare with the following...

page.title: Strategies Practiced in Jessica’s Lesson
page.contents:
ActivitiesStrategies Addressed
One-question-interview technique about culture; matching halves of sentences describing customs in the United States. ANTICIPATE CONTENT; PREVIEW AND PREDICT: Both of these activities activate prior knowledge about the topic and provide learners with a frame of reference for listening.
Listen first for where the person traveled from and what surprised him or her. LISTEN TO CONFIRM CONFIRMATIONS (i.e., how do the speakers’ experiences compare with their own); LISTEN FOR GIST: The first time learners listen, they listen only for main ideas.
Jigsaw Part 1: Listen and fill in grid A or grid B LISTEN FOR SPECIFIC INFORMATION: Using the partially filled grids allows learners to focus on only some of the information; they listen selectively.
Jigsaw Part 2: Mingle to exchange information from grids RECOGNIZE THE STRUCTURE of a text through the graphic organizer (categories) and THEN FIND FURTHER EVIDENCE TO SUPPORT A CLAIM: what can be surprising when crossing cultures.
Follow-up mingle grid ANALYZE RELATIONSHIPS between speakers and with personal experiences. SYNTHESIZE INFORMATION we hear with information from other sources.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0180.mp3

Audio transcript


What did you discover? Each task aligns with a particular listening strategy. Jessica gets the learners thinking about the topic of cultural differences so that when they listen to the video for the first time, they can compare their experiences with those described in the video. This focuses learners’ attention on the connections between their own experience or prior knowledge and what the speakers in the video say. When they listen the first time, they only need to get the main ideas, or listen for gist. With the next listening, they fill in only one grid, which is partially complete already. They use the strategy of listening for specific information. Then as they mingle to share what they found, they can see the structure of the text overall and also find evidence to support the idea that crossing cultures can have some challenges. As they interview one another at the end, they can analyze the relationships between the speakers in the video and some cultural practices they may encounter here in the United States. A follow-up writing assignment could ask learners to compare and contrast their experiences with those of the speakers in the video, which also would give them practice in synthesizing information from multiple sources. The unscripted video clips give practice in the kind of authentic listening learners will encounter at work, in further education, or in their community. Also notice how Jessica’s approach gave them practice with graphic literacy and note taking, which we will turn to now.

You have reached the end of this lesson.  You may review any of the content in this lesson using the Lesson Menu on the left of the screen.

If you have finished viewing the lesson, (1) click the NEXT button on this screen to indicate completion in your progress tracker.  Then, (2) return to the home page to select your next activity.  Activities you have completed will be checked off in your progress tracker.

page.title: High-Beginning-Level English Language Acquisition page 3
page.contents:
Finally, see how asking the right questions allows learners to find evidence to support a claim.

Mahatma Gandhi is a very famous civil rights leader from India. He believed in non-violent action. Many people, for example Martin Luther King Jr. and Nelson Mandela, followed his ideas. Gandhi lived in England and South Africa before he was famous in India.

Gandhi was born in 1869. He got married in 1883. He had four sons, the first born in 1888 and the last in 1900. Gandhi studied law in England from 1888-1891. From 1891-1893 he tried to practice law in India but he was unsuccessful. He moved to South Africa in 1893 and spent most of his time there until 1915. In India, he led the fight for Indian independence from Britain in 1947. He was in prison many times for his protests and was killed in 1948.

True or False: Gandhi was married before he was 15 years old.

How do you know?

True or False: He had a son before he finished school in England.

How do you know?

True or False: All of his sons were born before he left India for South Africa.

How do you know?

Find evidence to support claims:

  • To answer Question 1, the reader must look carefully at the dates in the text to see that it is true. The reader practices numeracy to determine he was 14 when he married.
  • These questions prompt students to analyze the information, not simply repeat facts as they are presented (e.g., He had a son before he finished school in England.) His first son was born in 1888, but he was in law school in English until 1891.

Task: Take a few minutes to reflect on how you could apply the techniques outlined in this lesson in one of your classes.

page.title: High-Beginning-Level English Language Acquisition page 2
page.contents:
Now see what happens when learners are asked to read and fill in a simple graphic organizer instead of answering a series of comprehension questions.

Mahatma Gandhi is a very famous civil rights leader from India. He believed in non-violent action. Many people, for example Martin Luther King Jr. and Nelson Mandela, followed his ideas. Gandhi lived in England and South Africa before he was famous in India.

Gandhi was born in 1869. He got married in 1883. He had four sons, the first born in 1888 and the last in 1900. Gandhi studied law in England from 1888-1891. From 1892-1893 he tried to practice law in India but he was unsuccessful. He moved to South Africa in 1893 and spent most of his time there until 1915. In India, he led the fight for Indian independence from Britain in 1947. He was in prison many times for his protests and was killed in 1948.

Scan for specific information:
The timeline reading task prompts the reader to scan for dates and then the information connected to that date.

Recognize the structure of a text:
The timeline signals to the reader that this is a chronology.

Transfer information to other contexts:
Reading and filling in the timeline demonstrates that there is a connection between the text and a visual representation.

Interpret information presented in variety of forms:
Transferring information from a text to a visual representation gives direct practice in interpreting information in a variety of forms.

page.title: High-Beginning-Level English Language Acquisition page 1
page.contents:
Many textbooks and curricula include a reading text with a series of questions (true/false, open ended, or multiple choice). See what happens when learners start with a K-W-L chart as a prereading activity.

Mahatma Gandhi

K

What do you know?

W

What do you want to learn?

L

What did you learn?



Anticipate content; preview and predict:
Using a K-W-L chart allows students to explore their prior knowledge about a topic.

The accompanying visual provides a prompt for sharing what they already know and would like to learn.

Read to confirm predictions:
The K column directs student reading; students may read more selectively, looking for information to confirm predictions.

The W column helps personalize the reading task, which can lead to higher levels of engagement.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0080.mp3

Audio transcript


As you review this lesson, notice all the different reading strategies learners need to employ as they read about the early years in the life of Mahatma Gandhi. See how the task types promote those strategies.

page.title: Survey of Your Current Practices
page.contents:
Now that we have explored the types of texts learners encounter and the types of reading strategies they need practice in, take a few minutes to answer the following questions. If you are working with a colleague, compare and discuss your answers.

1. What kinds of texts do you include in your lessons? How would you categorize them? Are they nonfiction (informational, procedural, environmental print) or fiction?

2. What kind of practice do learners have reading and interpreting charts, tables, or other graphics?

3. What reading strategies do learners practice in your classes?

4. From what you have explored so far in the unit, what types of texts or strategies have you overlooked?

Share your responses to this activity in your Community of Practice.

page.title: Scaffolding
page.contents:
Although these reading strategies might seem quite complex for beginning-level ELLs, scaffolding practice with the strategies can be done in numerous ways, as the next examples will demonstrate. As learners become more advanced in their language skills, we can be more and more explicit in naming the strategies with ELLs. We will begin by exploring how this looks in a beginning-level reading lesson.

Task: Before continuing, turn to a short survey on your current practices. If you are working with others, share your ideas.

page.title: Strategies for Comprehending Complex Texts at Work, Home, or School
page.contents:
StrategyPurpose
Recognize the structure of a text Analyze the structure of a text; how specific sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text relate to each other and the whole.
Find evidence to support claims Identify the main points and claims made in a text; identify evidence that supports those claims.
Transfer information to other contexts Recognize the connections between what is presented in a text with an accompanying visual (chart of graph); transfer information from the text to a visual representation.
Interpret information presented in variety of forms Recognize what information charts, tables, or graphs presents.
Summarize text and synthesize information from multiple texts Determine central ideas or themes of a text and analyze their development; summarize the key supporting details and ideas.
Analyze relationships within a text Analyze how and why individuals, events, and ideas develop and interact during the course of a text.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0070.mp3

Audio transcript


When reading more complex informational texts and documents, we employ higher order reading strategies. We analyze the structure of a text, including how specific sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text relate to each other and the whole. Does the text represent a narrative, a process, or a chronology? As we read, we identify the main points and claims made in a text and then identify evidence that supports those claims. Often, a text is accompanied by a graphic, so we need to recognize the connections between what is presented in the text with the accompanying visual (chart or graph). Often, we need to read and then transfer information from the text to a visual representation ourselves. When interpreting information presented in a variety of forms, we need to recognize what information is presented in charts, tables, or graph. Is it showing comparisons, cause-effect relationships, or categorization? Carlos will encounter these kinds of texts often if he pursues a teaching license, not only in courses and textbooks but also in the forms or applications he encounters.

page.title: What Reading Strategies Are Used Daily?
page.contents:
Reading StrategyPurpose
Anticipate content; preview and predict Pictures, the title, subheadings, and captions allow us to make predictions about  the content of a text.
Read to confirm predictions Check to see if predictions are right or wrong.

Skim

 Read quickly to get a general idea (gist) of a text.
Scan Read only for the information we need.
Read for details Read for detail (intensive reading), or to understand the text in its entirety.
Make inferences Interpret and make inferences about what we have read. -Make logical connections between ideas in a reading.

Audio transcript


We use a variety of reading strategies every day. We approach a text with certain expectations, for example, the weather page will tell us high and low temperatures. The table of contents will overview what is in a textbook. We preview and make predictions as we approach a reading by looking at the headings, pictures, and graphics. We draw on prior experience with the topic. As we read, we check to see if our predictions are right or wrong. Sometimes we read something only for the main ideas; other times, we scan for specific information, for example, the departure time of a bus or our name and hours on a work schedule in a break room. Other times we read more intensively, especially when reading informational texts for school or work or instructions. We also interpret information and make inferences, reading between the lines, and we make logical connections between ideas. We probably do not think about these strategies very consciously. Learners such as Carlos who have prior formal schooling in their own language will likely make use of these strategies as well; we need to highlight and practice them in English. For those with more limited formal schooling, such as Aadan, these types of strategies can take years to acquire, so we need to embed practice with them early and often in ELA classes.

A life-skills curriculum often focuses on environmental print. Learners need practice with all types of authentic texts.

For a review of the benefits and examples of authentic texts, see the fact sheet on using authentic materials (CALPRO, 2007).
